subject: Re: [junit] written recommendation of super.setUp/tearDown ?
msgSnippet: Do we know whether JUnit 4 will be resolving this design smell , i.e. will it no longer require subclasses of TestCase to explicitly remember to call

Subject: Re: [junit] written recommendation of super.setUp/tearDown ?

Do we know whether JUnit 4 will be resolving this "design smell", i.e. will=
 
it no longer require subclasses of TestCase to explicitly remember to cal=
l 
super.setUp and super.tearDown() ?

One other thing that has to be remem=
bered, that I always initially forget, 
is that--at least in my test fixtur=
es--you'll want to call super.setUp() 
_first_ in your subclass's overridin=
g method, but you'll want to call 
super.tearDown() correspondingly _last_ =
in its overriding method ...


On 27/07/05, Cedric Beust <cbeust@...=
> wrote:
> 
>  > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com]=
 On 
> > Behalf Of Russell Gold
> 
> > On 7/26/05, Dave Brosius <dbrosius@q=
is.net> wrote:
> > > I have it in my head that the junit folks recommend al=
ways calling 
> > > super.setUp/tearDown from a user declared setUp/tearDow=
n, 
> > even if the 
> > > JUnit test in question is directly derived from =
TestCase. However i 
> > > cannot find any written (web page) recommendatio=
n to so. Is 
> > this still 
> > > the case? Is there a documented recommen=
dation some where?
> > 
> > Even if you cannot find the page, this is defin=
itely a good 
> > idea. If you decide at a later time to have your test cas=
e 
> > extend something besides TestCase, your invocations of 
> > super.se=
tUp/tearDown will already be in place.
> 
> Yup, it's the best way, but it'=
s unfortunate that JUnit forces you to do
> that, because having to call su=
per is a clear design smell in OO design
> (because if somebody subclasses =
your class and forget to call super, it 
> will
> break). In short, it defe=
ats the purpose of polymorphism.
> 
> -- 
> C=E9dric
> http://testng.org
> =

> 
>
